elements.content: Four novel coordination polymers based on asymmetric triangular 5-(4′-carboxylphenyl) nicotinic acid (H2cpna), namely, Ni(cpna)(H2O)2 (1), M2(cpna)2(H2O)3·0.5H2O·DMF [M = Ni for (2), Co for (3)] and Ni3(Hcpna)2(cpna)2(H2O)4·2H2O (4), have been synthesized under solvothermal conditions. All of the four compounds contain low nuclear metal clusters as secondary building units (SBUs). Complex 1 exhibits two-dimensional (3,6)-connected (43)2(46.66.83)-kgd topology, in which cpna ligands and edge-shared dinuclear SBUs act as 3-connected and 6-connected nodes, respectively. Compounds 2 and 3 are constructed by corner-shared dinuclear SBUs and show an unprecedented (3,6)-connected chiral (42.6)2(44.62.88.10)-anh (flu-3, P6222) topology. In 4, linear trimers are ligated by six cpna ligands to form a planar (43)2(46.66.83)-kgd layer, and adjacent layers are further linked by Hcpna– ligands through Ni–O and Ni–N bonds to form three-dimensional (3,8)-connected (43)2(46.618.84)-tfz-d net. Both 1 and 4 crystallize in the triclinic crystal system with symmetric space group P̅1, which result in an equal ratio of (R)- and (S)-cpna isomers. Isostructural 2 and 3 crystallize in a trigonal crystal system with the chiral space group P3221, and a single crystal contains a sole optical isomer of cpna, although bulk crystals are a racemic mixture. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements reveal ferromagnetic coupling of edge-shared dimers in 1, antiferromagnetic coupling of corner-shared dimers in 2 and 3, and ferrimagnetic coupling of linear trimers in 4.

elements.content: With the use of a potential axial chiral triangular 5-(4′-carboxylphenyl) nicotinic ligand, four novel low nuclear metal cluster-based binodal coordination polymers, including a (3,6)-connected kgd layer and an unprecedented chiral anh network, as well as a (3,8)-connected tfz-d network, have been synthesized under solvothermal conditions. Magnetic measurements reveal ferromagnetic coupling of an edge-shared dimer, antiferromagnetical coupling corner-shared dimer, and ferrimagnetic behavior of a linear trimer.

Magnetic measurements reveal ferromagnetic coupling of an edge-shared dimer, antiferromagnetical coupling corner-shared dimer, and ferrimagnetic behavior of a linear trimer.

elements.content: The design and construction of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted great attention not only because of their charming topologies but also due to their potential applications as functional materials in gas storage/separation, ion exchange, chemical sensor, molecular magnetism, heterogeneous catalysis, luminescence, and drug delivery. Over the past few decades, much effort has been devoted to obtain functional MOF materials by modifying the secondary building units (SBUs) and controlling them for required products via selection of different organic ligands. The well-known metal carboxylate clusters, such as M2(O2C)4, Zn4(μ4-O)(O2C)6, and M3(μ3-O)(O2C)6, have widely been utilized as square, octahedral, and triangular prismatic SBUs to build interesting networks and functional materials. Moreover, paramagnetic metal clusters as SBUs can afford more possibilities in molecular magnets, including single-molecule magnets, single-chain magnets, spin-crossover magnets, and spin-canting magnets. On the other hand, aromatic multicarboxylates such as benzene di-, tri-, and tetra-carboxylates, as well as their derivatives, are employed frequently to construct MOFs due to their varied coordination capability. Compared to the aromatic multicarboxylates, the elongated bridging pyridyl carboxylic acids are less used.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and construction of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted great attention not only because of their charming topologies but also due to their potential applications as functional materials in gas storage/separation, ion exchange, chemical sensor, molecular magnetism, heterogeneous catalysis, luminescence, and drug delivery. Over the past few decades, much effort has been devoted to obtain functional MOF materials by modifying the secondary building units (SBUs) and controlling them for required products via selection of different organic ligands. The well-known metal carboxylate clusters, such as M2(O2C)4, Zn4(μ4-O)(O2C)6, and M3(μ3-O)(O2C)6, have widely been utilized as square, octahedral, and triangular prismatic SBUs to build interesting networks and functional materials. Moreover, paramagnetic metal clusters as SBUs can afford more possibilities in molecular magnets, including single-molecule magnets, single-chain magnets, spin-crossover magnets, and spin-canting magnets. On the other hand, aromatic multicarboxylates such as benzene di-, tri-, and tetra-carboxylates, as well as their derivatives, are employed frequently to construct MOFs due to their varied coordination capability. Compared to the aromatic multicarboxylates, the elongated bridging pyridyl carboxylic acids are less used.

elements.content: Network topology is an important aspect in the design and analysis of MOFs. Topological analysis for MOF materials reveals that the nets with high frequency are those with single and low-connected nodes, such as uninodal 3-connected, 4-connected, and 6-connected nets. However, high-connected nets with mixed connectivity such as (3,6)-, (4,6)-, (4,8)-, (3,7)-, (3,8)-, (3,10)-, and (3,12)-connected frameworks are sporadically documented because of coordination number and geometric limitation. The utilization of metal clusters as SBUs could efficiently reduce the coordination number and geometric limitations, and therefore, it has became a feasible synthesis strategy to design high-connected coordination frameworks. The structural geometries of SBUs are dependent on many factors such as solvent, temperature, molar ratio of raw materials, pH value, and so on. Therefore, the construction of MOFs with desired topologies and specific properties is still a far-reaching challenge. With the above consideration, a new asymmetric triangular ligand, 5-(4′-carboxylphenyl) nicotinic acid (H2cpna), was selected to construct coordination architecture. The H2cpna ligand possesses the following advantageous characteristics: (i) It is a rigid ligand with two carboxylate groups that possess a variety of coordination modes with possible syn- and anti- conformations and multiple bridging moieties to coordinate several metal ions and form SBUs (Scheme ). Meanwhile, pyridyl can complement the dicarboxylate groups in the coordination. (ii) The asymmetric triangular H2cpna ligand tends to act as a 3-connected node to link metal clusters to form binodal (3,4)-, (3,6)-, (3,8)-connected frameworks. (iii) More importantly, the pyridyl and phenyl rings of H2cpna are noncoplanar and can give different dihedral angles through rotation of a C–C single bond, thus H2cpna is a potential ligand with axial chirality. In this paper, we present four novel coordination polymers based on three types of SBUs with (3,6)- and (3,8)-connected networks, namely, Ni(cpna)(H2O)2 (1), [M2(cpna)2(H2O)3]·0.5H2O·DMF [M = Ni (2), Co (3)] and [Ni3(Hcpna)2(cpna)2(H2O)4]·2H2O (4). Complex 1 represents a two-dimensional (2D) (3,6)-connected (43)2(46.66.83)-kgd layer with the cpna ligand as the 3-connected node and the edge-shared Ni2 dimer as the 6-connected node. Isostructural 2 and 3 contain corner-shared dimeric SBUs and show an unusual (3,6)-connected chiral (42.6)2(44.62.88.10)-anh (flu-3,P6222) topology. Compound 4 exhibits (3,8)-connected (43)2(46.618.84)-tfz-d topology with the linear trimer as the eight-connected node. To the best of our knowledge, 2 and 3 are the first samples of hexagonal anatase (anh) topological net among the (3,6)-connected MOFs. Different magnetic interactions, including antiferromagnetic, ferrimagnetic, and ferromagnetic couplings were observed.

elements.content: All the starting materials were purchased of commercial reagent grade. Elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. The Fourier transform-infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range of 400–4000 cm–1 on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum BXII spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected with a Bruker D8 advance diffractometer. The magnetic measurements were made with Quantum Design SQUID MPMS XL-5 instruments. Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed under static air atmosphere using a SETARAM LABSYS thermo-gravimetric analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Gas-adsorption measurements (N2, H2, and CO2) were performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface-area and pore-size analyzer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All the starting materials were purchased of commercial reagent grade. Elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. The Fourier transform-infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range of 400-4000 cm-1 on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum BXII spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected with a Bruker D8 advance diffractometer. The magnetic measurements were made with Quantum Design SQUID MPMS XL-5 instruments. Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed under static air atmosphere using a SETARAM LABSYS thermo-gravimetric analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Gas-adsorption measurements (N2, H2, and CO2) were performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 surface-area and pore-size analyzer.

elements.content: A mixture of NiCl2·6H2O (23 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2cpna (25 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2O (2 mL), and acetonitrile (4 mL) in the molar ratio of 1:1:1100:770 was stirred in air for 30 min. The resulting solution was transferred into a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor, which was heated at 150 °C for 90 h. After cooling to room temperature, light green crystals of 1 as a single phase were recovered in 30% yield based on NiCl2. The yield was found a little elevated after purifying the ligand. Anal. Calcd for C13H11NNiO6: C, 46.48; H, 3.30; N, 4.17. Found: C, 45.8; H, 3.61; N, 4.23. IR (KBr, cm–1): 34620s, 2960w, 1626s, 1574w, 1220 m, 1076w.

A mixture of NiCl2⋅6H2O (23 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2cpna (25 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2O (2 mL), and acetonitrile (4 mL) in the molar ratio of 1:1:1100:770 was stirred in air for 30 min. The resulting solution was transferred into a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor, which was heated at 150 °C for 90 h. After cooling to room temperature, light green crystals of 1 as a single phase were recovered in 30% yield based on NiCl2. The yield was found a little elevated after purifying the ligand. Anal. Calcd for C13H11NNiO6: C, 46.48; H, 3.30; N, 4.17. Found: C, 45.8; H, 3.61; N, 4.23. IR (KBr, cm-1): 34620s, 2960w, 1626s, 1574w, 1220 m, 1076w.

elements.content: Method A: Solvothermal reaction of NiCl2·6H2O (36 mg, 0.15 mmol), H2cpna (25 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2O (2 mL), acetonitrile (2 mL), and DMF (2 mL) in the mole ratio 3:2:1100:390:300 was sealed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless container, which was heated to 120 °C and held for 114 h. After cooling to room temperature, blue-green block crystals of 2 were obtained in a yield of 28% (based on Ni). Method B: Solvothermal reaction of NiCl2·6H2O (37 mg, 0.15 mmol), H2cpna (25 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2O (3 mL), and DMF (3 mL) in the mole ratio 3:2:1600:390 was stirred in air for 30 min. The resulting solution was sealed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless container, which was heated to 120 °C and held for 114 h. After cooling to room temperature, blue-green block crystals of 2 were obtained in a yield of 41% (based on Ni). Anal. Calcd for 2 C29H27N3Ni2O12.5: C, 47.39; H, 3.70; N, 5.72. Found: C, 47.58; H, 3.52; N, 5.84. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3480–3462sb, 3275–2920s, 1660–1556sb, 1404s, 1270m, 1108w, 1054m.

elements.content: Crystallographic data of 1, 3, and 4 were collected on an Oxford Gemini diffractometer (Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å). Data reduction was accomplished by the CrysAlisPro (Oxford Diffraction Ltd., version 1.171.33.55) program. Crystal data of 2 was collected using a Bruker SMART APEX CCD area detector diffractometer using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710 73 Å) by the ω and φ scan mode. The program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. All of the structures were solved by direct methods and refined by a full-matrix least-squares technique based on F2, using the SHELXL 97 program. All the structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods with SHELXL. All nonhydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. All hydrogen atoms of organic ligands were generated theoretically onto the specific carbon atoms and refined isotropically with fixed thermal factors. Drawings of the molecule were performed with the program Diamond. Further details for structural analysis are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and bond angles of 1–4 are shown in Table S1 of the .

X-ray single crystal structural analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in triclinic space group P̅1. As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit consists of one crystallographically independent nickel(II) ion, two coordinated water molecules, and one cpna2– anion. All atoms localize on general positions. The Ni(1) with slightly distorted octahedral coordination geometry is six-coordinated by one nitrogen (N1b), three carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2, O2c, and O3a) from three individual cpna2– groups, and two oxygen atoms (O1w and O2w) from two coordinated water molecules. The Ni(1)–N distance is 2.096(3) Å while Ni(1)–O distances are in the range of 2.027(3)–2.154(2) Å (Table S1 of the ). The cis-L–Ni(1)–L (L = O, N) bond angles are in the range of 80.40(9)–95.23(11)°, and the trans-L–Ni(1)–L (L = O, N) bond angles are in the range of 171.23(11)–177.73(10)°. The coordination mode of cpna2– ligand in 1 is shown in Scheme (mode I). The carboxylate groups adopt μ2–η2:η0 and μ1–η1:η0 coordination modes. The cpna in the asymmetric unit shows that the (R)-isomer and the dihedral angles of pyridyl and phenyl rings in the cpna2– ligand are 29.31° (Scheme S1 of the ). Due to the existence of the inversion center in the P̅1 group space, the framework of 1 is centro-symmetric and there is a 1:1 ratio of (R)-cpna to (S)-cpna isomers.

Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure

X-ray single crystal structural analysis reveals that 1 crystallizes in triclinic space group P̅1. As shown in Figure a, the asymmetric unit consists of one crystallographically independent nickel(II) ion, two coordinated water molecules, and one cpna2- anion. All atoms localize on general positions. The Ni(1) with slightly distorted octahedral coordination geometry is six-coordinated by one nitrogen (N1b), three carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2, O2c, and O3a) from three individual cpna2- groups, and two oxygen atoms (O1w and O2w) from two coordinated water molecules. The Ni(1)-N distance is 2.096(3) Å while Ni(1)-O distances are in the range of 2.027(3)-2.154(2) Å (Table S1 of the ). The cis-L-Ni(1)-L (L = O, N) bond angles are in the range of 80.40(9)-95.23(11)°, and the trans-L-Ni(1)-L (L = O, N) bond angles are in the range of 171.23(11)-177.73(10)°. The coordination mode of cpna2- ligand in 1 is shown in Scheme  (mode I). The carboxylate groups adopt μ2-η2:η0 and μ1-η1:η0 coordination modes. The cpna in the asymmetric unit shows that the (R)-isomer and the dihedral angles of pyridyl and phenyl rings in the cpna2- ligand are 29.31° (Scheme S1 of the ). Due to the existence of the inversion center in the P̅1 group space, the framework of 1 is centro-symmetric and there is a 1:1 ratio of (R)-cpna to (S)-cpna isomers.

elements.content: It is interesting that adjacent two nickel atoms are linked by two carboxylate oxygen atoms to generate an edge-shared dimeric SBU with a Ni···Ni distance of 3.25 Å (Figure b). Each dimeric SBU is surrounded by six cpna2– groups. Meanwhile, each cpna2– is connected to three dimers to yield a 2D layer (Figure c). In accordance with the simplification principle, the dinuclear SBUs can be considered as six-connected nodes, and the cpna2– ligands can be simplified as three-connected nodes. The overall structure of 1 can be described as a 2D (3,6)-connected kgd net with a short Schläfli symbol of {(43)2(46.66.83)} (Figure d). The 2D wavy layers are further extended into a 3D metal–organic supramolecular framework via weak C–H···O hydrogen bonds [C3···O4, 3.157(4) Å; C–H–O, 119(3)] (Figure S1 of the ).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray analyses reveals that 2 and 3 are isostructural, and thus only the structure of 2 is described herein in detail. Complex 2 crystallizes in the trigonal space group P3221, and the asymmetric unit consists of one crystallographically independent nickel site, one and a half coordinated water molecules, and one cpna2– group (Figure a). The O2w localizes in a special position with occupancy of 0.5. Similar to 1, Ni(1) in 2 shows a slightly distorted octahedral geometry coordinated by one N atom and three carboxylate O atoms from three individual cpna2– groups and two O atoms of two coordinated water molecules. The Ni(1)–N distance is 2.109(5) Å, and the Ni(1)–O distances are in the range of 2.007(4)–2.163(3) Å. The L–Ni(1)–L (O, N) bond angles are in the range of 82.14(16)–174.08(18)°. The cpna2– group in 2 adopts coordination type II (Scheme , mode II) with the two carboxylate groups adopting the μ1–η1:η0 and bidentate syn–syn μ 2–η1:η1 coordination mode, respectively. The dihedral angle of the pyridyl and phenyl rings in cpna2– ligand is 37.73°. Unlike 1, the framework of 2 is chiral because all cpna2– groups have the same configuration within a single crystal. The configuration of cpna2– in the X-ray single crystal is (R)-cpna. In spite of this, bulk crystals of 2 and 3 consist of approximately equal crystals of different chirality. The solvent-accessible volumes calculated from PLATON are 37.3% for 2 and 44.0% for 3. The voids are occupied by solvent molecules, which are removable from the robust crystalline architectures.

elements.content: Different from 1, the basic unit in 2 is a corner-sharing dimeric SBU linking through μ2-O2w with a Ni···Ni separation of 3.60 Å (Figure b). Each dinuclear SBU is surrounded by six cpna2– and each cpna2– ligates three dimers, which result in a (3,6)-connected 3D framework. Topological analysis gives the long Schläfli symbols for the 3-connected node of 4.4.6 and 6-connected node of 4.4.4.4.6.6.8.8.82.82.82.82.85.85.1016. Therefore, the resulting (3,6)-connected net can be rationalized as anh (also flu-3,6-P6222) topology (Figure d) with the short Schläfli symbol (42.6)2(44.62.88.10).

elements.content: To the best of our knowledge, this (3,6)-connected anh topology has remained unreported in MOFs until now. It should be noted that there are many differences between this net and the classic (3,6)-connected 3D nets such as the rutile net {rtl, Schläfli symbol (42.6)2(42.610.83)}, pyrite net {pyr, Schläfli symbol (63)2(612.83)}, and anatase net {ant, (42.6)2(44.62.88.10)} (Figure S4 of the ). (i) The presence of the 10-membered circuit in anh net may be the largest difference from commonly observed rtl and pyr net. For rtl and pyr nets, the largest circuit is an 8-membered circuit. (ii) The anh net in RCSR is described as hexagonal anatase with the space group of P6222, while ant net is a tetragonal anatase with the space group of I41/amd. (iii) The anh net is chiral while rtl, pyr, and ant nets are centrosymmetric. Although the topological symbol of flu-3,6-P6222 is reminiscent of infrequent (3,6)-connected flu-3,6-C2/c net, the space group and Schläfli symbol indicate an apparent difference. The flu-3,6-C2/c net in RCSR belongs to the C2/c space group and has a Schläfli symbol of (42.6)2(44.62.87.102).

elements.content: Compound 4 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P̅1, and the asymmetric unit consists of two crystallographically independent nickel sites, one partly deprotonated Hcpna– ligand, one cpna2– ligand, two coordinated water molecules, and one lattice water molecule (Figure a). All atoms localize on general positions except for Ni(2) that has an occupancy of 0.5. The Ni(1) ion is six-coordinated by two N atoms from one cpna2– and one Hcpna– group, two carboxylate O atoms from two individual cpna2– groups, and two O atoms of two coordinated water molecules. Ni(2) shows a slightly distorted octahedral coordination geometry ligated by four O atoms from two individual cpna2– and two individual Hcpna–, and two O1w from coordinated water molecules. The Ni(1)–N and Ni(2)–N distances are 2.116(3) Å and 2.143(4) Å, respectively. The Ni–O distances are in the range of 2.024(3)–2.088(3) Å. The L–Ni(1)–L (O, N) and L–Ni(2)–L (O, N) bond angles are in the range of 85.62(15)–177.65(13)° and 84.91(11)–180.0°, respectively. The cpna2– ligand adopts a coordination mode III with the two carboxylate groups, taking a μ2–η1:η1 bidentate mode and a μ1–η1:η0 monodentate mode, respectively. The Hcpna– takes a coordination mode IV, in which the deprotonated carboxylate group shows a μ1–η1:η0 monodentate mode. The dihedral angles of the pyridyl and the phenyl rings in cpna2– and Hcpna– are 37.69° and 33.25°, respectively, corresponding to the (S)-cpna2– and (S)-Hcpna in the asymmetric unit. There exist inversion centers in 4 which lead to an equal number of (R)-cpna2–/-Hcpna– and (S)-cpna2–/-Hcpna– and centrosymmetric framework of 4.

elements.content: In 4, two Ni(1) and one Ni(2) ions are ligated together by two μ2–O1w to generate linear trinuclear SBUs with a Ni···Ni separation of 3.64 Å and the angle of Ni1–Ni2–Ni1A is 180° (Figure b). Each trinuclear SBU is surrounded by six cpna2– via Ni–N and Ni–O bonds to form a 2D layer [Ni3(cpna)(H2O)]2– (Figure c). The 2D layer can be described as a planar hexagonal kgd net, considering the trimers as six-connected nodes and the cpna2– ligands as three-connected nodes (Figure S3 of the ). It should be mentioned that the 2D layer in 4 is planar hexagonal, which is different from that wavy kgd layer in 1. Adjacent layers are further linked by Hcpna– groups via Ni–N and Ni–O bonds to result in the binodal (3,8)-connected tfz-d net with a short Schläfli symbol of (43)2(46.618.84) (Figure , panels d–e).

elements.content: It is well-known that the construction of the metal–organic frameworks under solvothermal conditions is easily affected by physical or chemical factors. Many factors such as types of starting materials, pH value, relative molar ratio, solvent, reaction time, and temperature can influence the formation of the final product. The syntheses of 1–4 rely on solvothermal treatment of a mixture of metal chloride and H2cpna ligands. It is worth emphasizing that solvent and reaction temperature play key roles in the formation of 1–4. At 120 °C, a mixture of NiCl2, H2cpna, H2O, and acetonitrile in the molar ratio 1:1:1100:770 resulted in 4, which contains linear trinuclear SBUs. When the temperature is increased to 150 °C, compound 1 with 2D layer structure based on an edge-shared dimer was isolated from the same starting materials, molar ratio, and solvents. In comparative experiments with different solvent ratios of H2O to acetonitrile, no crystal was produced. This phenomenon implied that temperature and solvent ratio were crucial for the formation of these MOFs. When DMF was substituted for acetonitrile with the molar ratio of metal to ligand in 3:2, crystals of 2 and 3 were generated, which also were available in a higher yield from a mixture of NiCl2·6H2O:­H2cpna:­H2O:­DMF in a 3:­2:­1600:­390 ratio. It means that solvents play an important role in the synthesis of 2 and 3.

Synthesis Chemistry

It is well-known that the construction of the metal-organic frameworks under solvothermal conditions is easily affected by physical or chemical factors. Many factors such as types of starting materials, pH value, relative molar ratio, solvent, reaction time, and temperature can influence the formation of the final product. The syntheses of 1-4 rely on solvothermal treatment of a mixture of metal chloride and H2cpna ligands. It is worth emphasizing that solvent and reaction temperature play key roles in the formation of 1-4. At 120 °C, a mixture of NiCl2, H2cpna, H2O, and acetonitrile in the molar ratio 1:1:1100:770 resulted in 4, which contains linear trinuclear SBUs. When the temperature is increased to 150 °C, compound 1 with 2D layer structure based on an edge-shared dimer was isolated from the same starting materials, molar ratio, and solvents. In comparative experiments with different solvent ratios of H2O to acetonitrile, no crystal was produced. This phenomenon implied that temperature and solvent ratio were crucial for the formation of these MOFs. When DMF was substituted for acetonitrile with the molar ratio of metal to ligand in 3:2, crystals of 2 and 3 were generated, which also were available in a higher yield from a mixture of NiCl2⋅6H2O:H2cpna:H2O:DMF in a 3:2:1600:390 ratio. It means that solvents play an important role in the synthesis of 2 and 3.

Magnetic Properties

Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements were performed on crystalline samples of 1-4 in the temperature range of 300-2 K with a field of 1000 Oe. The isothermal field-dependent magnetization M(H) at 2 K at a field up to 50 kOe and the M versus H plots for 1-4 are shown in Figure .

elements.content: As shown in Figure , the χm T value of 1 at room-temperature per Ni2 unit is 2.91 cm3 K mol –1, which is already higher than the expected value of 2.0 cm3 K mol–1 for two spin-only Ni(II) ion with S = 1 and g = 2.00. Upon sample cooling, the χm T values increase continuously to a maximum 3.81 cm3 K mol –1 at 14 K and then decreases abruptly to 1.28 cm3 K mol –1 at 2 K. The increase in the χm T value with a decreasing temperature represents a characteristic feature of intradimer ferromagnetic interaction. The sharp decrease of the χm T value at a very low temperature region may be attributed to either a zero-field splitting factor or interdimer antiferromagnetic interactions. The magnetic data in the range of 20–300 K followed the Curie–Weiss law with a Curie constant of C = 2.86 cm3 K mol–1 and a Weiss constant of θ = 2.15 K (Figure S5 of the ). The positive θ value indicates the presence of ferromagnetic interaction between Ni ions. The shortest Ni···Ni distance is 3.25 Å. For 1, the saturated magnetization of 3.83 Nβ per Ni2 unit at the highest field of 50000 Oe is close to the expected value of 4.0 Nβ for two ferromagnetic Ni(II) ions. The observed ferromagnetic interactions should be mainly from a magnetic superexchange through the O atom bridges.

elements.content: For 2, the χm T value at 300 K per Ni2 unit is 2.35 cm3 K mol–1. Along with the lowering temperature, the χm T value decreases slowly and then more rapidly below 60 K to reach a value of 0.37 cm3 mol–1 K at 2 K (Figure ). The shape of the χm T versus T curve is characteristic of the occurrence of antiferromagnetic coupling. The susceptibility above 25 K obeys the Curie–Weiss law with a Curie constant of C = 2.37 cm3 K mol–1 and Weiss constant of θ = −10.68 K (Figure S6 of the ). The negative θ value indicates the presence of antiferromagnetic interaction. Since the structure of 2 is characteristic of a well-isolated corner-shared Ni dimer, the magnetic data for χm T were fitted by the isotropic Heisenberg S 1 = S 2 = 1 spin-coupled dimer model [H = −2JS 1 S 2, eq ]. χ M T = N g 2 β 2 T k ( T − θ ) × 2 e x + 10 e 6 x 1 + 3 e 2 x + 5 e 6 x ; ⁣ χ = J k T This simple model gives a very satisfactory fitting of the magnetic properties in the whole temperature range with the following set of parameters: g = 2.070(7), J = −2.10(5) K, zJ′ = −0.50(1) K, and R = 4.0 × 10–6 (solid line in Figure ). The g values are reasonable, falling within the range of 2.0–2.4 for octahedral Ni(II). The small negative J also confirms weak antiferromagnetic interactions between the two Ni ions. The J and g values in this compound are comparable with those of other reported weak antiferromagnetic interactions between dimeric Ni ions. There are two possible magnetic exchange pathways for 2. One is intradimeric exchange, mainly propagated via the μ2–OH2 bridge and the three atom syn–syn carboxylate bridge. The large Ni–Oaq–Ni angle of 112.76(7)° usually leads to antiferromagnetic interaction. The other is a very weak interdimeric exchange via a pyridine ring with a NiII...NiII distance of ca. 8.3914(1) Å.

elements.content: For isostructural 3, the experimental χm T value at 300 K per Co2 unit is 5.11 cm3 K mol –1, which is larger than the spin-only value of 3.75 cm3 K mol –1 for two high-spin Co(II) atoms and suggests a contribution of orbital angular momentum typical of the local 4 T 1g ground term. With lowering the temperature, the value of χm T decreases continuously to a value of 3.47 cm3 K mol –1 at 30 K (Figure ). Upon further cooling below 30 K, the sample undergoes a more rapid decrease in χm T and reaches 0.70 cm3 K mol –1 at 2 K. The magnetic susceptibilities obey the Curie–Weiss law above 45 K with C = 5.49 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = −23.46 K (Figure S7 of the ). The negative Weiss constant and the decrease of χm T with a decrease of the temperature do not definitely denote an antiferromagnetic interaction within a corner-shared dimer in 3. The depopulating of the higher Kramers doublets, caused by splitting of the 4 T 1g ground triplet state under the combined action of spin–orbit coupling and noncubic crystal-field terms, also contributes to this phenomenon. For an octahedral Co(II) ion, the effect of the spin–orbit coupling usually yields a Kramers S = 1/2 state at low temperatures with an average g tensor of 13/3. If we take into consideration S eff = 1/2 and g = 13/3, the magnetization of the 4.45 Nβ per Co2 unit for 3 at 2 K (Figure ) at the highest field of 50000 Oe is close to the expected saturation value of 4.34 Nβ for ferromagnetic or paramagnetic Co(II) ions.
elements.clean_text: For isostructural 3, the experimental χm T value at 300 K per Co2 unit is 5.11 cm3 K mol -1, which is larger than the spin-only value of 3.75 cm3 K mol -1 for two high-spin Co(II) atoms and suggests a contribution of orbital angular momentum typical of the local 4 T 1g ground term. With lowering the temperature, the value of χm T decreases continuously to a value of 3.47 cm3 K mol -1 at 30 K (Figure ). Upon further cooling below 30 K, the sample undergoes a more rapid decrease in χm T and reaches 0.70 cm3 K mol -1 at 2 K. The magnetic susceptibilities obey the Curie-Weiss law above 45 K with C = 5.49 cm3 K mol-1 and θ = -23.46 K (Figure S7 of the ). The negative Weiss constant and the decrease of χm T with a decrease of the temperature do not definitely denote an antiferromagnetic interaction within a corner-shared dimer in 3. The depopulating of the higher Kramers doublets, caused by splitting of the 4 T 1g ground triplet state under the combined action of spin-orbit coupling and noncubic crystal-field terms, also contributes to this phenomenon. For an octahedral Co(II) ion, the effect of the spin-orbit coupling usually yields a Kramers S = 1/2 state at low temperatures with an average g tensor of 13/3. If we take into consideration S eff = 1/2 and g = 13/3, the magnetization of the 4.45 Nβ per Co2 unit for 3 at 2 K (Figure ) at the highest field of 50000 Oe is close to the expected saturation value of 4.34 Nβ for ferromagnetic or paramagnetic Co(II) ions.

elements.content: As shown in Figure , the χm T product per Ni3 unit at 300 K for 4 is 4.16 cm3 K mol –1, which is higher than expected 3 cm3 K mol –1 for three magnetically isolated Ni(II) ions with S = 1. Temperature dependences of the magnetic susceptibility above 20 K were well-fitted by the Curie–Weiss expression with C = 4.26 cm3 mol–1 K and θ = −14.06 K (Figure S8 of the ). Upon sample cooling, the χm T value decreases and reaches a minimum at 6.5 K, then increases smoothly, typical of ferrimagnetic-like behavior. In consideration of the fact that trinuclear clusters are well-separated in 4, the temperature dependence of χm T was analyzed by an isotropic isolated centro-symmetrical three-spin model (H = −2J 1{S 1 S 2 + S 2 S 3}). The best-fit parameters were J = −2.80(6), zJ′ = 0.077(1), g = 2.19(5), R = 2.60 × 10–4 (R = [∑(χobs – χcalcd)2/∑χobs 2]1/2) (solid line in Figure ). Magnetically, the antiferromagnetic coupling within the Ni3 trimer is transmitted mainly via a μ2–OH2 water bridge with the exchange angle Ni–Oaq–Ni at 120.89(9)° and the syn–syn carboxylate bridges (Ni–OCO–Ni). Three antiferromagnetic-coupled Ni ion in trimer will give ferrimagnetic behavior with a ground spin of S = 1, which is supported by the field dependence of the magnetization. The saturated magnetization at the highest field of 50000 Oe is 3.11 Nβ per Ni3 unit for 4.

elements.content: To study the porosity of 2, gas sorption measurements were carried out. The gas physisorption experiments were performed at 77 K for N2 and H2, but 273 K for CO2. For this purpose, the synthesized sample was immersed in methanol for 2 h, and fresh methanol was added after the extract was decanted, which was operated at least five times. Then, the crystals were allowed to immerse in methanol for 24 h to remove the guest solvates. After the removal of methanol by decanting, the sample was dried under a dynamic vacuum at 80 °C overnight. Before the measurement, the sample was activated at 90 °C for 5 h on the apparatus, resulting in green crystalline material. Unfortunately, the nitrogen and hydrogen physisorption measurements at 77 K resulted in a low uptake and no appreciably surface area (Figures S9 and S10 of the ). On the other hand, the activated sample for adsorption CO2 gas was observed with an increase in the CO2 pressure, and the uptake at 850 mmHg is 29.10 cm3 g–1 (Figure ).
elements.clean_text:
Gas Sorption

To study the porosity of 2, gas sorption measurements were carried out. The gas physisorption experiments were performed at 77 K for N2 and H2, but 273 K for CO2. For this purpose, the synthesized sample was immersed in methanol for 2 h, and fresh methanol was added after the extract was decanted, which was operated at least five times. Then, the crystals were allowed to immerse in methanol for 24 h to remove the guest solvates. After the removal of methanol by decanting, the sample was dried under a dynamic vacuum at 80 °C overnight. Before the measurement, the sample was activated at 90 °C for 5 h on the apparatus, resulting in green crystalline material. Unfortunately, the nitrogen and hydrogen physisorption measurements at 77 K resulted in a low uptake and no appreciably surface area (Figures S9 and S10 of the ). On the other hand, the activated sample for adsorption CO2 gas was observed with an increase in the CO2 pressure, and the uptake at 850 mmHg is 29.10 cm3 g-1 (Figure ).

elements.content: In summary, four novel coordination polymers with binodal nets have been synthesized and characterized and successfully constructed by potentially axial chiral asymmetric triangular pyridyl carboxylate linkers and di/trinuclear SBUs, through tuning the temperature and solvents. Complexes 2 and 3 represent (3,6)-connected topology with the short Schläfli symbol (42.6)2(44.62.88.10), which is the first example with hexagonal anatase (anh) topology for MOFs. Complex 1 shows 2D (3,6)-connected (43)2(46.66.83)-kgd layer, while complex 4 represents 3D (3, 8)-connected (43)2(46.618.84)-tfz-d net with a (3,6)-connected planar kgd layers. 1 and 4 show centrosymmetric frameworks with an equal ratio of (R)- and (S)-cpna isomers. Isostructural 2 and 3 present chiral skeletons, and a single crystal contains a sole optical isomer of cpna, although bulk crystals are racemic mixtures. This work may provide an alternative approach to design and synthesis of novel chiral frameworks with utilizing binaphthol-like axial chiral ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, four novel coordination polymers with binodal nets have been synthesized and characterized and successfully constructed by potentially axial chiral asymmetric triangular pyridyl carboxylate linkers and di/trinuclear SBUs, through tuning the temperature and solvents. Complexes 2 and 3 represent (3,6)-connected topology with the short Schläfli symbol (42.6)2(44.62.88.10), which is the first example with hexagonal anatase (anh) topology for MOFs. Complex 1 shows 2D (3,6)-connected (43)2(46.66.83)-kgd layer, while complex 4 represents 3D (3, 8)-connected (43)2(46.618.84)-tfz-d net with a (3,6)-connected planar kgd layers. 1 and 4 show centrosymmetric frameworks with an equal ratio of (R)- and (S)-cpna isomers. Isostructural 2 and 3 present chiral skeletons, and a single crystal contains a sole optical isomer of cpna, although bulk crystals are racemic mixtures. This work may provide an alternative approach to design and synthesis of novel chiral frameworks with utilizing binaphthol-like axial chiral ligands.

A mixture of NiCl2·6H2O (23 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2cpna (25 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2O (2 mL), and acetonitrile (4 mL) in the molar ratio of 1:1:1100:770 was stirred in air for 30 min. The resulting solution was transferred into a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor, which was heated at 150 °C for 90 h. After cooling to room temperature, light green crystals of 1 as a single phase were recovered in 30% yield based on NiCl2. The yield was found a little elevated after purifying the ligand. Anal. Calcd for C13H11NNiO6: C, 46.48; H, 3.30; N, 4.17. Found: C, 45.8; H, 3.61; N, 4.23. IR (KBr, cm–1): 34620s, 2960w, 1626s, 1574w, 1220 m, 1076w.

Synthesis of [Ni<sub>2</sub>(cpna)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>]·0.5H<sub>2</sub>O·DMF (<bold>2</bold>)

Method A: Solvothermal reaction of NiCl2·6H2O (36 mg, 0.15 mmol), H2cpna (25 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2O (2 mL), acetonitrile (2 mL), and DMF (2 mL) in the mole ratio 3:2:1100:390:300 was sealed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless container, which was heated to 120 °C and held for 114 h. After cooling to room temperature, blue-green block crystals of 2 were obtained in a yield of 28% (based on Ni). Method B: Solvothermal reaction of NiCl2·6H2O (37 mg, 0.15 mmol), H2cpna (25 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2O (3 mL), and DMF (3 mL) in the mole ratio 3:2:1600:390 was stirred in air for 30 min. The resulting solution was sealed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless container, which was heated to 120 °C and held for 114 h. After cooling to room temperature, blue-green block crystals of 2 were obtained in a yield of 41% (based on Ni). Anal. Calcd for 2 C29H27N3Ni2O12.5: C, 47.39; H, 3.70; N, 5.72. Found: C, 47.58; H, 3.52; N, 5.84. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3480–3462sb, 3275–2920s, 1660–1556sb, 1404s, 1270m, 1108w, 1054m.

Synthesis of [Co<sub>2</sub>(cpna)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>3</sub>] ·0.5H<sub>2</sub>O·DMF (<bold>3</bold>)

The synthetic procedure of 3 is similar to that of 2, method B, with CoCl2·6H2O (36 mg, 0.15 mmol) instead of NiCl2·6H2O. Red blocklike crystals of 3 were obtained in a yield of 39% (based on Co). Anal. Calcd for 3, C29H27Co2N3O12.5: C, 47.36; H, 3.70; N, 5.71. Found: C, 48.31; H, 3.82; N, 5.41. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3418sb, 1624s, 1572s, 1402s, 1284w, 1112w, 872 w.

Synthesis of [Ni<sub>3</sub>(Hcpna)<sub>2</sub>(cpna)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>4</sub>]·2H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>4</bold>)

A mixture of NiCl2·6H2O (19 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2cpna (25 mg, 0.1 mmol), H2O (2 mL), and acetonitrile (4 mL) in the molar ratio of 1:1.25:1300:960 was stirred in air for 30 min and then sealed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless container and heated to 120 °C for 144 h. After it was cooled to room temperature and subjected to filtration, light blue block crystals of 4 in 35% yield were recovered. The yield was found a little elevated after purifying the ligand. Anal. Calcd for C52H40N4Ni3O22: C, 50.01; H, 3.23; N, 4.49. Found: C, 47.84; H, 2.93; N, 4.29. IR (KBr pellet, cm–1): 3405sb, 1637 m, 1394 s, 1172–1020 wb.

Synthesis Chemistry

It is well-known that the construction of the metal–organic frameworks under solvothermal conditions is easily affected by physical or chemical factors. Many factors such as types of starting materials, pH value, relative molar ratio, solvent, reaction time, and temperature can influence the formation of the final product. The syntheses of 1–4 rely on solvothermal treatment of a mixture of metal chloride and H2cpna ligands. It is worth emphasizing that solvent and reaction temperature play key roles in the formation of 1–4. At 120 °C, a mixture of NiCl2, H2cpna, H2O, and acetonitrile in the molar ratio 1:1:1100:770 resulted in 4, which contains linear trinuclear SBUs. When the temperature is increased to 150 °C, compound 1 with 2D layer structure based on an edge-shared dimer was isolated from the same starting materials, molar ratio, and solvents. In comparative experiments with different solvent ratios of H2O to acetonitrile, no crystal was produced. This phenomenon implied that temperature and solvent ratio were crucial for the formation of these MOFs. When DMF was substituted for acetonitrile with the molar ratio of metal to ligand in 3:2, crystals of 2 and 3 were generated, which also were available in a higher yield from a mixture of NiCl2·6H2O:­H2cpna:­H2O:­DMF in a 3:­2:­1600:­390 ratio. It means that solvents play an important role in the synthesis of 2 and 3.

As shown in Figure , the χm T value of 1 at room-temperature per Ni2 unit is 2.91 cm3 K mol –1, which is already higher than the expected value of 2.0 cm3 K mol–1 for two spin-only Ni(II) ion with S = 1 and g = 2.00. Upon sample cooling, the χm T values increase continuously to a maximum 3.81 cm3 K mol –1 at 14 K and then decreases abruptly to 1.28 cm3 K mol –1 at 2 K. The increase in the χm T value with a decreasing temperature represents a characteristic feature of intradimer ferromagnetic interaction. The sharp decrease of the χm T value at a very low temperature region may be attributed to either a zero-field splitting factor or interdimer antiferromagnetic interactions. The magnetic data in the range of 20–300 K followed the Curie–Weiss law with a Curie constant of C = 2.86 cm3 K mol–1 and a Weiss constant of θ = 2.15 K (Figure S5 of the ). The positive θ value indicates the presence of ferromagnetic interaction between Ni ions. The shortest Ni···Ni distance is 3.25 Å. For 1, the saturated magnetization of 3.83 Nβ per Ni2 unit at the highest field of 50000 Oe is close to the expected value of 4.0 Nβ for two ferromagnetic Ni(II) ions. The observed ferromagnetic interactions should be mainly from a magnetic superexchange through the O atom bridges.

Three antiferromagnetic-coupled Ni ion in trimer will give ferrimagnetic behavior with a ground spin of S = 1, which is supported by the field dependence of the magnetization. The saturated magnetization at the highest field of 50000 Oe is 3.11 Nβ per Ni3 unit for 4.
